nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py.message: Instead of a boolean cross_cell_move column, how about adding two new fields called source_cell_uuid and dest_cell_uuid? That would align a whole lot better with the existing source_compute/source_node and dest_compute/dest_node fields we currently have in here.

We could, I was just able to get by with the source_compute to look up the source cell mapping via the host mapping for the source compute:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603930/15/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py@871

It's not a huge deal to me either way. Using the cross_cell_move flag is nice in the compute/RT code where I need to determine what's going on, but that could also just be a property on the Migration object which returns True if those other fields are set.

> FWIW, I think it'd potentially be worth just checking this each time instead of storing it, if that would be possible and not too wasteful. I'm not sure where all this is checked (and how often), but we have the source and dest hosts, which means we should be able to (a) determine if they're in the same cell from the top, and (b) check to see if either is "in my cell or not" from the bottom.

It's used in a few places, both in the API and compute layers. You'd probably have to pull down https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603930/ and grep for it.

So I was about to say something like "storing a boolean seems wasteful when we could store something useful and imply the boolean". I still feel that way. However, I really don't want the cells to know anything about their ... cell, and since the migration is stored in the cell DB, this would be such a violation. So, while I don't love storing a boolean as I think it's too specific and likely to be "not enough" some time later, I'd prefer it over violating the layers.

FWIW, I think it'd potentially be worth just checking this each time instead of storing it, if that would be possible and not too wasteful. I'm not sure where all this is checked (and how often), but we have the source and dest hosts, which means we should be able to (a) determine if they're in the same cell from the top, and (b) check to see if either is "in my cell or not" from the bottom.

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message:
I'm not a fan of adding links to bugs in code, but I'd make an exception here and add the link to [1]. I would also add a note about this option being "temporary" and how we plan on removing after 'N' releases. We want to move everyone to the new "correct" world.

[1] - https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1837819

Generally I'm a big fan of putting power in the hands of the operator, but this one feels like a really hard sell!

Either we expect one of the primary nodes to return a response or we don't ... and if we *don't* then what are we even doing.  I'm not oblivious to the fact that service quality metrics might be related to # of 5XX responses, but I see no good reason the client response shouldn't indicate the difference between "not found" and "unable to contact primaries" - we should tell the truth.

Perhaps the config option is:

"return server errors as client errors"

... and then why limit it to just this one case that shows up under the duress of extreme load.

oh dear

swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py.message: so given that we're not going to be returning from a *good* bucket...
but we did *have* a "good" bucket, it just wasn't "good enough"
then we can say "if *this* bad bucket is older than our "not good enough bucket"
skip it, and look for some other like... "better" bad bucket?

I'm not so sure that ECGetResponseBucket is actually well suited for this, though :-/

I've been seeing some 'Etag mismatch' log lines, and I *think* it's because this one bad_bucket mixes 404s (which don't have etags) with 416s (which *do*).

Maybe I could resolve that somewhat by looking at self.timestamp_str to decide whether to do the etag check? Feels hacky.

I'm also weirded out by the fact that none of

- 404 with a timestamp,
- 304,
- 412, or
- 416

is considered "good"...
oic, bad_bucket.get_responses is just all the bad responses - thank you for clarifying my misconception
Technically, it's all the same bad bucket, but yeah. The idea is that we ought to go digging through the bad in case one of them knows about a newer tombstone which would prompt us to 404.

Did the hack, if for no other reason than that I *really* want that etag mismatch to be a GIANT red flag and false positives diminish that.

Nothing broke, which means that I probably ought to be adding more tests...

And if none of the bad buckets are "good enough" we end up cooking up a response on no information at all.... hrmm, not obvious that's the best way to proceed but seems likely to be better than using sort of "known out of date" information
If we wanted to return non-durable, we'd take this out...

... and this. Maybe we could just kinda *stop tracking durability*? Just get me enough conns to reconstruct, dammit!

Oh, but maybe we'd still want it to separate not-enough-frags-but-should-be-durable (503) from not-enough-frags-and-not-durable (404).
so by default we do not consider 404s from handoffs, so we do handle this block of code.

test/unit/proxy/controllers/test_obj.py.message: i think this is no longer true, correct?

it's pretty obvious to me this test and others were setting up a "failure to return partial data" - where the disks had lots of indication that was *something* out there - but couldn't piece it together.

And it's not like they're mixing in a tombstone here and there that indicates the problem was probably a "cleanup issue" - the test looks more like "imagine something is wrong in the cluster"

I think it's a positive change to represent this to the client as a server error :+1:
Mixing in a tombstone is a good idea... hmm. :-/

Carrying forward Thiago's comment:

> i think this is no longer true, correct?
I'm not convinced that this should have changed.

yeah I'd say it should 200!  I was never quite sure I believed a cluster could have enough non-durable frags to reconstruct and yet not repair in a reclaim age

In fact, I had argued if we thought that likely we might ought go ahead and have the re-constructor DIG and mark durable if it's rebuildable!

we could log more when dropping the responses...
yeah, i'm not sure this was ever correct - but I remember it being a decision we made at time time - same as above worth additional conversation
As above, not so sure that this should change.

neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py.message: I know this is a WIP patch, but I don't understand this logic. "rescoped_subnet_ids" will be always a subset of "all_affected_subnet_ids". Am I wrong?

Actually, this logic is correct. We don't need to go network-by-network. Pulling all the subnets from each affected network and subtracting the subnets from the pool will tell us whether to block the operation or not. I'm building up some test cases.

The idea here is to subtract the rescoped subnets from all possible subnets in the address scope. If there are any subnets left over, we can't do the operation because it would leave subnets stranded in a different address scope on the same network. Because we are allowing subnets from different pools to exist on the same network, this is looking for any subnets that would not stranded. all_affected_subnet_ids could be renamed so it's clearer what this means, it is just all the subnets in the address scope we are moving the subnet pool out of.

If rescoped_subnet_ids is only a proper subset, it means we can't perform the operation. If the 2 sets are equivalent, then we can proceed.

This could use a little work because we may have to go network-by-network with this check.
Ok, now I see. "all_affected_subnet_ids" must be the same as "rescoped_subnet_ids"

These updates look good. The user will only ever encounter these exceptions when creating a subnet. Subnet onboard is unaffected by this, and because subnet updates are not how you move subnets between subnet pools, creation is the only time you would ever see this. Because of this, my thinking is that it will be clear to the user that they can't build a subnet on the the given network unless they use a different subnet pool.

Yes, it is very confusing and there was a lot of head-scratching over this. I'm not seeing an alternative though. This is a function of the way the prefix delegation pool works. We don't keep a record for it and we never instantiate an OVO for it, we simply pass around this constant. All other solutions I explored were a whole lot more invasive and even more messy than this is.

See L552 below for more context.

I'm OK with this anyway.

hehehe L552 should be here (only a nitty nit)
Sorry, but I'm trying to understand the logic here. Why network_scope (address scope) should be None?

Ufff thanks for the explanation. At least for me, this wasn't evident.

if network_scope null --> no address scopes on the subnets or the network. That means you can't add a new subnetpool to this net.

All subnets of the same address family must be allocated from subnet pools that participate in the same address scope. However, if you don't use address scopes the address scope of the subnets on the network will be the "null" scope. In that case, network_scope will be None. network_scope will be None in cases where you haven't used address scopes.

This block is checking to see whether the subnet you are attempting to create is coming from a different subnet pool than other existing subnets when you aren't using address scopes.

I also forgot to mention that unless you use address scopes, the current restriction of 1 subnet pool per network continues to be enforced. So if network_scope is None, then it is true and expected that you can't create a subnet from a different subnet pool on the  network.
Subnet onboard exists to enable adopting subnets into pools and shifting things around into an address scope. It actually is possible, just use subnet onboard.

this would change host form a positional argument to a optional argument which is incorrect for microverions <2.53
as they are required to use the force-down action api endpoint.

it would also break backward compatiblity so im not sure this is allowed by defualt.

i think you will have to make the parser construction condtional on the microversions so that it remains a postional arg for older microverions or somehow register it as both.

If I make parser construction conditional on the microversions then there are two below scenarios needs to taken care:

1. if microversion<=2.52 host and service arguments are positional and also if user dont specify the mocroversion then it will take default as 2.1 in that case also host and service are mandatory

2. if microversion>=2.53 id of the service as uuid is required argument.

I have tried below code:

compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute
if compute_client.api_version >= api_versions.APIVersion('2.53'):
	parser.add_argument(
		"id",
		metavar="<service_id>",
		help=_("Compute service(s) to update (ID only)")
	)
else:
	# For compute version 2.53 onwards 'force_service_down' API is superseded.
	parser.add_argument(
		"host",
		metavar="<host>",
		help=_("Name of host")
	)
	parser.add_argument(
		"service",
		metavar="<service>",
		help=_("Name of service (Binary name)")
	)
......

If tried to execute
$openstack help compute service set 

it shows output as:
'ClientManager' object has no attribute 'auth'

where did this range come from?
this is required for all micorversion as far as i can tell since the force down action endpoint was added in 2.11

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=update-forced-down-detail,update-compute-service-detail#update-forced-down
for microversion<-2.52 it takes host and service to update service and from 2.53 onwards this API is superseded by PUT /os-services/{service_id}.
same as above this should not be converted to a optional arguemtn both service and host are required aregument and therefore should be positional args.
you also can use it after but you have to use the /os-services/force-down api endpoint not hte compute service update endpoint /os-services/{service_id}

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/672577/

What I'd probably do is fix the immediate problem for using 2.53+ with the existing host and service options by looking up the service by host/binary to get the uuid id and then call the PUT /os-services/{service_id} API, and then in a separate change - which is not backportable - add the --id option which would be only available starting with 2.53 and mutually exclusive with --host and --service.

this likely should be in a mutually exclusive group with host and service.

paunch/utils/systemd.py.message:
Damien, I think we could remove that dependency, for two reasons:

* In THT, most of the services who rely on RabbitMQ and Galera don't have this depends_on configured; so the dropin will not be created for them, while we need it.
* All paunch-managed containers rely on paunch-container-shutdown.service (see L#97: After=paunch-container-shutdown.service); which itself has After=pacemaker.service (+ other things). So I think the ordering is done at that level; and we might not need to patch all services in THT to have depends_on galera/rabbitmq, since Pacemaker is already a dependency in paunch-container-shutdown.service.

What do you think?

Right, fair questions, let me try to elaborate  on my answer:

A - Why i think it should work

I added that line to limit the number of services that would need to fiddle with systemd transient scopes to the ones which have a currently known shutdown orderning constraint (e.g. nova-compute -> nova-libvirt). That is, only to the services which currently have a depends-on expressed in -t-h-t. I did that to limit the impact (performance and behaviour) to the needed services. Now let me explain why I think this should work.

There are two different use cases to consider:
- When we deploy with pacemaker-managed containers (i.e. HA overcloud).
In that case, pacemaker tweaks the transient scope files to prevent systemd from shutting down pacemaker-managed containers. So on shutdown, we are sure that openstack services will be shutdown _before_ pacemaker containers (thanks to "After=paunch-container-shutdown").

- When we deploy without pacemaker (i.e. undercloud, standalone)
In that case, mariadb/rabbitmq/whatnot are not configured to tweak the transient systemd scope, so on shutdown systemd could stop them at any time, especially before the openstack services. However I don't think this is a problem as currently there is no service defined in t-h-t which explicitely depends on mysql or rabbit. Besides, all openstack service are normally configured to survive disconnection to mariadb/rabbitmq/whatnot.


B - Why you could get rid of this "if" statement, and what would it cost
If you get rid of the if, then in in theory all paunch services will tweak their associated scope files, and that will force a "systemd daemon-reload" at every "systemctl start tripleo_{service}" operation. I can't say if this has a big impact on the system, so I think we should limit the tweak to the service we know for sure need it.

So in summary, my position is threefold:
- i think we can leave that if statement, to limit this tweak/hack to a few services.

- getting rid of that if statement might add some load on the system, although it's unsure.

- for undercloud and standalone only: eventually we may want to add some constraint to force mariadb/rabbit to stop after all other openstack containers, however we need to discuss how to do that in a way which would work with HA-containers, and that is out of the scope of that review IMHO.

Basically - yes. In the inherited class I can easily define list of resource types, which I'd like to have available in the cache. That's the easiest way for achieve this, without doing a horrible things ;)

Main issue was the fact, that such list was defined within create_cache_for_l2_agent function, which was called during initialization. And since CacheBackedPluginApi inherits from PluginApi, I cannot simply skip the initialization in class derived from CacheBakcedPluginApi, since all of the PluginApi attributes will be lost.

Cleanest solution IMHO would be to explicitly call initialization on CacheBackedPluginApi object, i.e.

   (ovs agent code)
   ...
   plugin_rpc = OVSPluginApi(topics.PLUGIN)  # derived from CacheBackedPluginApi
   plugin_rpc.spin_up_the_watchers()

so that before spin_up_the_watchers, I could influence on the list of desired resources to be watched, using some method. The other part is the custom resource type definition, but it's different story.

Also since this is the case perhaps reconsider all the README modifications here for now?

Yes. Apparently using include can introduce some change in behavior regarding variables. I seen this only in few cases and only regarding playbooks (include or role inside role worked without problems).


On purpose I avoiding touching those areas, the plan being to look depeer later on these (also testing with newer ansible).

We have a huge numebr of usages of role, so a gradual adoption should be better.

This is mostly about a role defining a variable which may no longer be addresable after the role runs. Newer versions of ansible have some extra arguments that can control its behavior (keep vs drop).

This is why it was safe to adop include_role on the last roel include in the playbook as nobody needed the vars after that. On previous ones, it needs testing.

old role should be obliterated from docs in the first place as hints people to use something that soon will not work.

Is not that variables are not working or there is something wrong with include_role itself, the bug I found is more about how we used it, making some assumptions based on previous behavior but which were never documented as desired.

Shortly, we should adopt include_role in all places where is working well and refactor our code to make it work in places where we discover issues.

test-requirements.txt.message: That's understandable I suppose. Perhaps we can at least do ~= though to get bug fixes if they get released

The problem with adding a new non-voting gate is that because it's non voting it leads to complacency.  It will require contributors to be vigilant with watching patches to fail this new non-voting gate.

In any case it's outside the scope of this patchset, but something we could bring up on Tuesday (06-Aug) team meeting.  Checking for outdated packages in general could be useful rather than checking for just yapf/flake8-import-order.
Going to keep pinned for now, across all projects I implement this change into.  Over time with your pipfile work I think this can be streamlined.

We used to have this, and it meant that gates broke each time a new version of yapf was released. If this is done across all projects, then all gates will be broken until re-formatting against the new yapf version can be done/merged. Being on the latest version of yapf immediately doesn't seem worth all that pain. So intentional planned upgrades of yapf (and likely flake8-import-order) seems preferable. Perhaps adding a non-voting gate which checks whether these and possibly other deps are up to date could inform when updates are needed, though that may be overkill.

roles/ensure-tox/tasks/main.yaml.message: why is PIP_DISABLE_XX and a specific tox version needed? Best to mention in commit message...

I added a -1 on Worflow on this change as it seems to need more work (see failures).

I added the line to disable version check to avoid an uneccesary HTTP request and spam on console as this will help nobody. 

It is outside the scope of this role to assure pip is recent.

I have nothign againt upgrading pip myself but getting an additional warning does not help anyone. The same warning will be visible anyway at the first execution of pip by the job.

The version condition on tox is related to the fact that version 3.2.1 was the first one to add support for plugin "requires".

Sadly for us I found out that upgrading tox breaks it because default PATH does not include ~/.local/bin - and the old "tox" script would fail to start.

Right approach on this is to assure that ~/.local/bin is at the top of the PATH, so the right executable would be used.

Newer operating systesm do this by default by on older ones this is not include in PATH.

We need to decide what to do in this case as this uncovers a real issue: installing with --user is not safe unless one of these two alternatives are used:

A) always use module calling method ($python_cmd -m tox)
B) assure the ~/.local/bin is in PATH and at the top.

I am curious what others think about this.

playbooks/templates/clouds/nodepool_clou.message:
Is this parameter supposed to specify the external network?
The tenant network for nodepool is openstackzuul if no
We do not want to use public_v4, as there are no ip's in the v4 pool for nodepool. the correct network is public_v6

fortnebula is an "ipv6 only" cloud. What we want to do is instruct openstacksdk to be happy with a public ipv6 address and a private ipv4 address and not request a floating ip.

I think setting this network to be the nat source will have sdk request fips from here?

Instead we should update this to explain to the sdk that it is ok to not request a floating ip (I don't know how to do that).

Yes, nat_source: true means "this is where you get floating ips from"

We could, as a workaround for now, try "nat_source: false"
